head.headtext: Testimony at a previous judicial proceeding—Nature of previous proceedings

para.paratext: For a statement from a previous hearing to be admissible,[1] the witness must have given testimony under oath and the opposing party afforded an opportunity to cross-examine the witness regarding his testimony.[2]

For example, courts have admitted prior testimony from probation revocation hearings[3] and license revocation hearings.[4] Prior testimony from a criminal proceeding may be used in a civil proceeding and visa versa.[5]

Also, the issues and parties at the previous hearing must have been substantially the same as at the present trial. The state is not the “same” party in another criminal case even against the same defendant.[6] Simply amending pleadings after a case is reversed on appeal does not make the second trial a different case.[7]

Early Georgia cases broadly interpreted the word “substantially,”[8] but in 1900 the Georgia Supreme Court restricted their scope in Hooper v. Southern Ry. Co.[9] In Hooper, the case was a suit for injuries against the railroad on behalf of a minor. In the second suit, the minor's father sued for loss of the minor's services due to his injury. The court held that the two parties and causes of action were not substantially the same.

In 1961, the Georgia Court of Appeals interpreted “substantially” more broadly in Myrick v. Sievers.[10] In that case, the court held admissible an inaccessible witness's deposition which was taken for use in a companion case growing out of the same automobile collision and against the same defendant. Although the plaintiffs were different, the issues were substantially the same in both cases.

In Prater v. State,[11] the Georgia Court of Appeals discusses the identity of issues and parties at length. In Prater, the state introduced evidence of another burglary against a defendant on trial for burglary and armed robbery. A witness, who was deceased at the time of the Prater trial, had testified in Tennessee about the other burglary at a commitment hearing and at an extradition hearing. In admitting the deceased witness' previous testimony, the court said, “We candidly admit that the differences here are probably as considerable, or more so, than the differences in any previously decided case allowing former testimony under [former] § 24-3-10. However, we feel that an enlightened view of [former] § 24-3-10 supports our conclusion that the parties and issues are substantially the same.”[12]

Today, the parties need only have had an opportunity and similar motive to examine the declarant at the former proceeding as they would have if the witness were available to testify in the current case. Thus, the issues involved in the prior proceeding need not be identical. In Knight v. State,[13] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the testimony of a deceased rape victim was admissible in a subsequent rape case involving a different victim where the issue and the parties were substantially the same and the defendant's counsel in the prior proceeding had cross-examined the deceased witness. The court stated that former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-10 “does not demand that all the issues or parties be the same but requires only that the issue on which the testimony was offered in the first suit be the same as the issue upon which it is offered in the second.”[14]

The Georgia Supreme Court reached a similar result in Pope v. Fields[15] and held that a testator's deposition testimony which was videotaped for a prior suit against her brother was admissible under former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-10 in a subsequent proceeding to probate her will. Her brother was a party to both proceedings and was the party against whom the testimony was offered at trial. The brother's attorney had an opportunity to question the testator at the deposition and the issues in both proceedings were substantially similar: the testator's health, her relationship with her family, her understanding of her financial affairs, and her intent in disposing of her property.

Likewise, in Martin v. State,[16] the court emphasized that the admissibility of evidence under the “prior testimony” exception to the hearsay rule hinges on the adequacy of an opportunity for cross-examination rather than on the type of proceeding in which the prior testimony was presented. The Court noted that it is well-settled that the qualifying adverb “substantially” in former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-10 means something less than “identical.”

The rule does not require that all the issues … in the two proceedings must be the same, but at most that the issue on which the testimony was offered in the first suit must be the same as the issue upon which it is offered in the second. Additional issues or differences in regard to issues upon which the former testimony is not offered are of no consequence. Moreover, insistence upon precise identity of issues [is] out of place with respect to former testimony where the question is … merely … the salvaging, for what it may be worth, of the testimony of a witness not now available in person.[17]

The court concluded that testimony given at a prior sentencing hearing was admissible in a later criminal trial because proving the aggravating circumstances beyond a reasonable doubt at the former was substantially the same issue as proving guilt beyond a reasonable doubt at the latter.[18]
Willingham v. State, 279 Ga. 886, 622 S.E.2d 343 (2005).
Hardeman v. State, 277 Ga. App. 180, 626 S.E.2d 138 (2006).
Vanhouten v. State, 193 Ga. App. 871, 389 S.E.2d 534 (1989).

See Gavan v. Ellsworth, 45 Ga. 283, 1872 WL 2565 (1872); Hardin v. State, 107 Ga. 718, 33 S.E. 700 (1899); Bennett v. State, 231 Ga. 458, 202 S.E.2d 99 (1973) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Crowder v. State, 237 Ga. 141, 227 S.E.2d 230 (1976)) and (overruled on other grounds by, Howard v. State, 237 Ga. 471, 228 S.E.2d 860 (1976)); Wiseman v. State, 249 Ga. 559, 292 S.E.2d 670 (1982); Littles v. State, 236 Ga. 651, 224 S.E.2d 918 (1976).
See also Littles v. Balkcom, 245 Ga. 285, 264 S.E.2d 219 (1980); Jones v. State, 250 Ga. 166, 296 S.E.2d 598 (1982); Kesler v. Veal, 165 Ga. App. 475, 300 S.E.2d 217 (1983).
Taylor v. State, 83 Ga. 647, 10 S.E. 442 (1889).
Lathrop v. Adkinson, 87 Ga. 339, 13 S.E. 517 (1891).

Gavan v. Ellsworth, 45 Ga. 283, 1872 WL 2565 (1872); Power v. Savannah, Skidaway and Seaboard R. Co., 56 Ga. 471, 1876 WL 3049 (1876); Atlanta and West Point R.R. v. Venable, 67 Ga. 697, 1881 WL 3462 (1881).
Hooper v. Southern Ry. Co., 112 Ga. 96, 37 S.E. 165 (1900).
Myrick v. Sievers, 104 Ga. App. 95, 121 S.E.2d 185 (1961).
Prater v. State, 148 Ga. App. 831, 253 S.E.2d 223 (1979).
In Transamerica Ins. Co. v. Thrift-Mart, Inc., 159 Ga. App. 874, 285 S.E.2d 566 (1981), the court said that the Prater case stated the “outside limits” of the concept and did not extend it.

Prater v. State was cited but not discussed in Barnes v. State, 256 Ga. 370, 349 S.E.2d 387 (1986). In this case, the defendant had called a witness at the committal hearing and examined him on direct examination. The state had cross-examined. After a showing that the witness was inaccessible at the trial, his prior testimony was properly admitted. The issues and parties were identical and it did not matter that the defendant had examined him on direct rather than on cross-examination.
Knight v. State, 210 Ga. App. 63, 435 S.E.2d 276 (1993).
Knight v. State, 210 Ga. App. 63, 66, 435 S.E.2d 276 (1993).
Pope v. Fields, 273 Ga. 6, 536 S.E.2d 740 (2000).
Martin v. State, 284 Ga. 504, 668 S.E.2d 685 (2008) (quoting Prater v. State, 148 Ga. App. 831, 253 S.E.2d 223 (1979)).
